Graphical abstract Two-dimensional Cu, Zn and Sn-based multimetallic sulfide nanosheets were prepared to construct multi-active sites for the immobilization and entrapment of polysulfides with offering better performance in liquid Li2S6-based lithium-polysulfide batteries. The lithium-sulfur battery has attracted enormous attention as being one of the most significant energy storage technologies due to its high energy density and cost-effectiveness. However, the “shuttle effect” of polysulfide intermediates represents a formidable challenge towards its wide applications. Herein, we have designed and synthesized two-dimensional Cu, Zn and Sn-based multimetallic sulfide nanosheets to construct multi-active sites for the immobilization and entrapment of polysulfides with offering better performance in liquid Li2S6-based lithium-polysulfide batteries. Both experimental measurements and theoretical computations demonstrate that the interfacial multi-active sites of multimetallic sulfides not only accelerate the multi-chained redox reactions of highly diffusible polysulfides, but also strengthen affinities toward polysulfides. By adopting multimetallic sulfide nanosheets as the sulfur host, the liquid Li2S6-based cell exhibits an impressive rate capability with 1200 mAh/g and retains 580 mAh/g at 0.5 mA/cm2 after 1000 cycles. With high sulfur mass loading conditions, the cell with 2.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading delivers a cell capacity of 1068 mAh/g and maintains 480 mAh/g with 0.8 mA/cm2 and 500 cycles. This study provides new insights into the multifunctional material design with multi-active sites for elevated lithium-polysulfide batteries. Keywords Multimetallic sulfide Nanosheets Multi-active sites Lithium-polysulfide battery 1 Introduction The continuously increasing demands on electric automobiles and portable power sources have led to crucial requirements for next-generation energy storage systems with high power densities and long cycle life [1–3]. However, most of rechargeable energy storage systems cannot reach such demands. Under this circumstance, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries may be a promising candidate due to their prominent theoretical capacity and energy density (1675 mAh/g and 2600 Wh/kg), natural abundance and low-cost sulfur materials [1–3]. However, the low electrical conductivities of sulfur and the “shuttle effect” of polysulfides hamper the development of the high-performance Li-S batteries. To address these shortcomings, state-of-the-art strategies have been developed through the integration of conductive and functional additives, including metal oxides, sulfides and nitrides [2,4–7]. Among them, the metal sulfides have shown strong adsorption/catalysis capacities for polysulfide intermediates, and meanwhile, they could largely lower the resistance of sulfur [8–10]. For example, Li group prepared a kind of Cu/Cu2S materials with 1200 mAh/g for Li-S cells, which could sustain 1000 cycles. The formation of Cu2S nanoflake arrays with tunable morphology and thickness could approach an equivalent sulfur uptake up to 5 mg/cm2 [10]. Wang group reported the ZnS nanospheres based Li-S battery, which has 589 mAh/g with 7 mg/cm2 sulfur loading after 200 cycles. As-synthesized ZnS-based kinetic analyses suggested that it not only facilities polysulfide redox kinetics in the liquid phase (Li2S8 to Li2S4), but also promotes the effective decompositions of lithium sulfides (Li2S2/Li2S) [8]. By providing an efficient sulfur host involving a three-dimensional graphene aerogel with SnS2 nanodots, Manthiram team showed that the Li-S battery with SnS2-graphene electrodes demonstrated a capacity of 1016 mAh/g with 300 cycles and an areal capacity of 11 mAh/cm2 [9]. These results reveal that the noticeably accelerated redox of liquid polysulfides to solid sulfur via the activated single-metal site and the enhanced electrochemical reactivity could be expected to reduce the migration possibility of polysulfides in the Li-S cell working [8–10]. However, due to the distinct electrochemical properties and different molecular structures of sulfur and lithium sulfides (S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2 and Li2S…), the catalytic function of the single active site may not contribute to the multi-chained polysulfide redox reaction equally [11–14]. This means that, to boost the performance of Li-S cells, an ideal catalyst material containing multiple active sites may further enhance redox conversion reactions of the different molecule-based polysulfides. Inspired by prior reports [3,8–10,15–19], multi-activated-site-based catalysts could be beyond the performance of the single site of materials in Li-S cells. Unfortunately, it remains a challenge to synthesize and design multimetallic materials. Nowadays, most studies focused on single-metallic sulfides due to the challenge in constructing complex crystalline structures and atom space configurations [15]. Therefore, the development of synthesis methods with precisely controlled elemental composition and phase, could bring a new repertoire of nanostructures with unprecedented properties and functionalities. Herein, we report a facile colloidal synthesis of Cu, Zn and Sn-based multimetallic sulfide nanosheets (Cu2ZnSnS4: CZSS) with exposed (0 0 2) facets by adopting the one-step thermal decomposition synthetic approach. The exposed (0 0 2) facets with high surface density generate a two-dimensional (2D) morphology of the wurtzite phase. The highly crystallized CZSS nanosheets can lower the charge transfer resistivity to enhance the performance of lithium-polysulfide cells in polysulfide redox reaction processes. By adopting electrochemical analysis and in-situ XPS analysis, this study has confirmed that the exposed (0 0 2) facets can lead to effective polysulfide catalysis processes via the interfacial synergistic effect of Cu, Zn and Sn-based multi-active sites in liquid Li2S6 systems. The cell (1.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading) suggests a cell capacity of 1200 mAh/g and retains 580 mAh/g at 0.5 mA/cm2 after 1000 cycles. During the high sulfur mass loading, the cell with 2.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading delivers a cell capacity of 1068 mAh/g and maintains 480 mAh/g at 0.8 mA/cm2 after 500 cycles. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of materials First, 2 mmol Copper(II) acetylacetonate, 1 mmol Zinc(II) acetylacetonate, and 1 mmol Tin(IV) chloride pentahydrate were transferred to a 100 mL three-necked flask involving 20 mL 1-dodecanethiol. Moisture and oxygen were repelled from the solution by raising the temperature to 110–120 °C (held for 30–35 min) under magnetic stirring and Ar protection. After that, the temperature was raised to 200–220 °C (with a rate of 3–4 °C/min) and held for 10–15 min, and later to 250–260 °C (with a rate of 3–4 °C/min) and held for 25–30 min. Then, the obtained products were precipitated and washed with cyclohexane and ammonium sulfide after cooling down the mixture to room temperature. Next, the as-prepared samples were annealed with the Ar atmosphere at 300–400 °C for 30–90 min. Finally, the products (CZSS) were successfully synthesized. For the control group of Cu2S synthesis, 0.6 g Cuprous thiocyanate were added into a three-necked flask with 100 mL oleylamine. With vigorous stirring, the flask with aerated Ar gas held at 130–140 °C for 30–40 min, and then was heated to 240–250 °C for another 30–40 min. After that, the reacted solution was rapidly cooled down to room temperature. The obtained products were centrifuged (with ethanol) and collected (after drying). 2.2 Material characterization Structures of samples were evaluated by employing Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (PANalytical, Empyrean). Morphologies and microstructures of samples were examined by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Gemini instrument operated at 5–15 kV). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images were acquired by adopting a Tecnai F20 transmission electron microscope (200 kV). In-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Scientific Nexsa XPS system with a monochromatic Al K α radiation (hν = 1486.7 eV) and a concentric hemispherical analyzer. Before all in-situ XPS measurements, with the argon-filled glovebox, batteries were disassembled, and the electrodes were rinsed with 3 mL (1:1 volume ratio) mixed solvents of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME). For the sample preparation and sample transfer, an airtight bottle was adopted to prevent air exposure. All XPS data analysis was carried out with Avantage software. 2.3 Electrochemical characterization Coin cells (CR2032) were employed for electrochemical measurements. They were assembled under an argon-filled glove box (H2O and O2 < 0.1 ppm). The active material (CZSS), conductive carbon black and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were mixed with a weight ratio of 7:2:1, and dispersed in N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) to form a homogeneous slurry. Then, the slurry coated uniformly onto the carbon cloth current collector (area: 2 cm2) to achieve an areal loading of 1.0–2.0 mg/cm2, and dried at 100 °C with a vacuum environment overnight (100 °C for 24 h). The lithium foil was adopted for the counter electrode, while the Celgard 2325 membrane was employed for the separator. The electrodes were protected by carbon paper. The high purity electrolyte was constructed by dissolving 1 M bis(trifluoromethane) sulfonamide lithium salt (LiTFSI) and 0.5 M LiNO3 in mixed solvents of 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) and 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) (1: 1volume ratio). Then, Li2S and sulfur powder (the molar ratio is 1 : 5) were introduced in the high purity electrolyte to generate 0.5 M Li2S6 (Li2S + 5S = Li2S6, the molar concentration was computed with the S atom). To obtain a uniform catholyte solution, the mixture was stirred on the hot plate at 50 °C under the Ar atmosphere. The cathode was then impregnated with a computed amount of the Li2S6-containing catholyte. For instance, 21 μL 0.5 M Li2S6-containing catholyte and 40–50 μL additional electrolyte (without Li2S6, only DOL solution, DME solution, LiTFSI and LiNO3 salts) are adopted to get 1.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading, while, 63 μL 0.5 M Li2S6-containing catholyte and 20–50 μL additional electrolyte (without Li2S6, only DOL solution, DME solution, LiTFSI and LiNO3 salts) are used to obtain 3 mg/cm2 sulfur loading. By employing a NEWARE BTS and LAND (CT2001A) battery tester, the galvanostatic discharge–charge measures were adopted with a range of 1.8–2.6 V (vs. Li/Li+) at various rates. C-rate currents and capacities were computed upon on sulfur (1C denotes 1600 mA/g). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis was employed on a Gamry potentiostat by adopting a sine wave of 10 mV amplitude with a frequency range between 100 kHz and 1 mHz. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) was used via the CHI660E potentiostat under a 0.1 mV/s scan rate. All cells were aged and then activated for several cycles before cyclic tests. 2.4 Computational methods and models By employing Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) package [20], all first-principles computations are run via the density functional theory (DFT). The electron interaction is described by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) modeling using Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional [21]. The projector augmented-wave (PAW) approach is adopted to demonstrate the relationships of ion cores and valence electrons [22]. A plane wave energy cutoff of 500 eV was applied and the 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grids were employed for the Monkhorst-Pack scheme. Geometry optimizations are carried out by the conjugated gradient approach and the convergence of 10−5 eV for energy and 0.01 eV/Å for force are used. The vacuum space was set to 15 Å to prevent the interplay between two periodic images. A surface slab model with 2 × 2 × 1 supercell (i.e. Cu32Zn16Sn16S64 containing 128 atoms) was used to describe the (0 0 2) surface of Wurtzite Cu2ZnSnS4. In this DFT model, the ratio of Cu, Zn and Sn is 2:1:1. Essentially, the model consisted of eight atomic layers (where the four outermost layers relax while the others are fastened). The adsorption energy (E ads) was counted via the formula of E ads = E total–E sub–E Li-S, where E total, E sub, and E Li-S were total energies of the entire system, of the substrate and of molecules (Li2S8 or Li2S6, Li2S4 or Li2S), respectively. A negative E ads indicated the lithium sulfides could be located on the surface steadily, and the more negative E ads implied the stronger adsorption capability between the lithium sulfides and the substrate. 3 Results and discussion The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) is employed as a crystal analysis technique to ensure the compositional homogeneity across the CZSS nanosheet. A resultant XRD diffract gram (Fig. 1 a) shows major reflections at 2-theta degree relating to (1 0 0), (0 0 2), (1 0 1), (1 1 0), (1 0 3) and (1 1 2) planes of a hexagonal structure, matching the simulated wurtzite crystalline structure (Fig. S1) (space group P63mc; a = b = 3.843 Å and c = 6.337 Å) [23,24]. One should be noticed that the Bragg peak intensities of (0 0 2) are larger than those of other patterns, which reveals the highly exposed (0 0 2) facets of CZSS [23,24]. Morphologies of CZSS are examined by employing both transmission electron microscope (TEM) and field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM). Mainly, hexagonal and quasi-polygonal shapes occur for the nanosheets (Fig. 1b and c), and the lateral sizes are approximately 300–400 nm. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Fig. 1d) described that the interplanar spacing (d spacing) of CZSS nanosheets is approximately 0.32 nm, matching the (1 0 0) planes of the wurtzite structure. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of CZSS nanosheets (the inset of Fig. 1d) could be assigned to the [0 0 1] zone axis of the wurtzite structure, confirming the well-crystallized nature of CZSS. The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) imaging (Fig. 1e) with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping (Fig. 1f-i) of Cu, Zn, Sn and S species via scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) implies the scatter behavior of Cu, Zn, Sn and S on the entire area, suggesting a high correlation of their spatial arrangement. In what follows, the cycling performance of the cell with a Li2S6-based CZSS cathode is investigated (Fig. 2 a and b). In the lithium polysulfide cell cycling, the cell (1.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading) shows a cell capacity of 1200 mAh/g and retains 500 mAh/g at 0.5 mA/cm2 after 1000 cycles with an approximately 96% Columbic efficiency (Fig. 2a). During the high sulfur loading, the cell with 2.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading delivers a cell capacity of 1068 mAh/g and retains 480 mAh/g at 0.8 mA/cm2 after 500 cycles with an approximately 97% Columbic efficiency (Fig. 2b). Previous studies of the performances of similar lithium-polysulfide batteries are collected in Table S1. Later, the SEM (Fig. S2) of the electrode shows that the coating of the sulfur-based materials on the interface of CZSS, and the CZSS retains its original structure (Fig. S3). The elemental mapping of Cu, Zn, Sn, S, Li, C, F and N species via SEM catches their spatial arrangement and correlation, suggesting the uniform coating of sulfur-based materials on CZSS (Fig. S2d–l). In the extreme conditions of sulfur mass loading (Fig. S4), the CZSS-based lithium polysulfide cell (with 4 mg/cm2 sulfur loading) delivers a high initial capacity of 820 mAh/g, and retains 780 mAh/g at 1.6 mA/cm2 with an averaged 99% Columbic efficiency after 50 cycles. To testify the stability of the Li2S6-based CZSS cathode (3.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading), the cell (Fig. 2c) delivers capacities as high as 1000, 870, 760 and 640 mAh/g at 2, 3, 4 and 5 mA/cm2, respectively. Then, decreasing the current density to 2 mA/cm2 would get a capacity of 820 mAh/g, demonstrating better reversibility and stability. Fig. 2(d) presented the charge/discharge voltage profiles during a cycling process. The two-step reduction reaction of sulfur (S8 to Li2S/Li2S2) and one oxidation reaction from Li2S2/Li2S to S8 can be obtained from the two distinct plateaus in the discharging graph and one plateau in the charging graph, respectively [8,13,25–27]. All curves presented clear and smooth plateaus during the discharge and charge processes of the lithium-polysulfide cell. According to the prior study [28], Cu2S nanosheets are synthesized for comparing with CZSS. From Fig. S5(a), XRD patterns of Cu2S nanosheets can be assigned to chalcocite Cu2S (JCPDS No. 09-0328). SEM images (Fig. S5b and c) present uniform hexagonal nanoplates of the obtained Cu2S, and the TEM image (Fig. S5d) suggests a side length of about 60 nm. In the lithium polysulfide cell cycling, the 2D-Cu2S-based cell (with 2.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading) shows a cell capacity of 440 mAh/g and retains 410 mAh/g at 0.8 mA/cm2 after 100 cycles with an approximately 97% Columbic efficiency (Fig. S5e). Compared to Cu2S materials, the as-prepared CZSS have better performance of lithium polysulfide cells, which may come from the interfacial multi-active catalytic sites. Further, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is employed to examine the charge transfer behavior and internal resistance of the Li2S6-based CZSS electrode (Fig. 2e) [12,29]. The Rs reveals the electron conduction phenomenon between the current collector and reaction sites in the high-frequency region. The Rp refers to the charge transfer behavior around the reaction sites/electrolyte interface in the medium-frequency region. The models of W and CPE represent the finite diffusion-controlled Warburg impedance and migration of Li ions in the bulk electrode, respectively [8,9,13,26,27,30,31]. The small difference of Rp semicircle after 250 and 500 cycles shows the stable charge transportation, which could be beneficial from the crystal structure of the CZSS-based solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) layer. What’s more, based on the cyclic voltammetry (CV) approach with 2.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading [13,26,27,32], the Randles-Sevcik equation could offer the diffusion coefficient (D Li +) of lithium ions, i.e., I p = 2.69 × 105 n 1/2 AD Li 1/2 V Li 1/2 C Li (I p: the current maximum; A: the electrode area; n: the number of transferred electrons; D: the diffusion coefficient; C: the concentration; and V: the scan rate). Then, the diffusion states of Li ions could get from the linear relationships of D and I A1 (or I C1, or I C2). Further, two cathodic peaks in each CV (Fig. 2f and g) curve are attributed to the transition from S8 to polysulfides and Li2S/Li2S2, whereas anodic peaks in each CV curve are ascribed to the formation of S8, which are oxidized from polysulfides. During the fifteen times scanning at 0.4 mV/s (Fig. 2f), the occurrence of the slight difference of polarized voltages (I: the maximum current) in the cathodic and anodic peaks could reveal the stable redox reaction process of S8 and Li2S/Li2S2 on CZSS (0 0 2) facets. Further, the increases of the scanning speeding (e.g. from 0.1 to 0.4 mV/s in Fig. 2g) raised the CV peak current and slightly shifted its position. Ordered Li+ diffusion-limited processes could be proved by a linear relationship when the curve of peak current plotted with the square root of the scan rate (Fig. 2h) [13,26,27,32–34]. Next, the symmetric cells (Fig. 3 a) are used to explore essentials, which enhances the electrochemical properties of lithium-polysulfide cells. The CZSS with carbon cloth (CZSS-CC) and current collector of carbon cloth (CC) loaded the same mass of Li2S6 in electrolytes. CV curves (Fig. 3b) show that the CZSS-CC-based cell has a higher current and multiple potential responses as compared to carbon cloth with Li2S6-containing electrolyte, which might suggest the high electrochemical activity of CZSS. In the symmetric cell of Li2S6-based CV, the oxidation process on one electrode could be balanced by the reduction process on the counter electrode (S8, Li2S6, Li2S…). During the CV test (Fig. 3b), multiple peaks could be from the multiple activated sites of CZSS, which are the combined outcome of the multi-catalysis of polysulfides in chained redox electrochemical reactions. Therefore, the multi-site catalyst CZSS for polysulfide conversion reactions could be similar to the “bifunctional catalysts” in oxygen electrochemical reactions [11–14,35], indicating that CZSS could be an effective catalyst for the oxidation of polysulfides to sulfur and reduction of polysulfides to Li2S2/Li2S [11–14,35]. The EIS spectra (Fig. 3c) indicate that the reaction semicircle of the CZSS-CC-based cell has a similar diameter with that of the CC-based cell, suggesting the minor difference of the charge transfer resistance for the two cells [27]. The chronoamperometric curves (Fig. 3d) disclose the occurrence of diffusion limitation phenomenon in the electrode interface (90 mA/cm2 for CZSS-CC and 27 mA/cm2 for CC). As shown by the straight line passing through the origin in the Cottrell plot (Fig. 3d) [36], the CZSS-CC-based cell has a higher current response than the CC-based cell, which suggests a better interaction between the Li2S6 and CZSS with exposed (0 0 2) facets. Furthermore, the in-situ XPS technology is adopted to study the polysulfide redox reaction process on the CZSS surface (Fig. 3e) [13,33,37]. The Fig. 3(f) provides four characteristic peaks for S 2p with a range of 174–159 eV, revealing the intrinsic Cu/Sn-S (165–160 eV) and Zn-S (163–160 eV) binding. It is worth noting that, the close electronegativity of Cu (1.90) and Sn (1.93) results in the overlap of the chemical bond energies of Cu-S and Sn-S, generating multiple peaks (Cu/Sn-S). The in-situ XPS fine spectra (Fig. 3g and h) demonstrate that the Li2S6-based cell with CZSS electrodes ran 1 and 500 times (1st and 500th) at 0.8 mA/cm2 after aged time. In Fig. 3(g), the new broad peaks could be attributed to the LiTFSI salt (171–167 eV), Cu/Sn-polysulfides (170–165 eV) and Zn-polysulfide (169–165 eV) binding, respectively. For the LiTFSI salt, those peaks could be originated from S = O or S–N bonds [11–13,37,38]. For the Cu/Sn-polysulfides and Zn-polysulfides, those peaks could be from the interfacial adsorption of CZSS (0 0 2) facets with polysulfides, deriving from the synergistic effect of the Cu, Zn and Sn-based multimetallic active sites [7,11,12,16,25,34]. In general, the interfacial adsorption offers an effective route of electron transport, enhancing the transition between solid–liquid (S8 to Sn 2−) and liquid–solid (Sn 2− to Li2S/Li2S2) and reducing the “shuttle reaction” of the sulfur redox electrochemistry [11,13,25,37]. Compared to Fig. 3(g), the minor change in the results of Fig. 3(h) indicates the stable Cu/Sn-polysulfides (170–167 eV) and Zn-polysulfides (169–166 eV) binding after 500 cycles, which would be beneficial to restrain the movement of polysulfides. Further, the adsorption behavior of lithium sulfides on the (0 0 2) facet of wurtzite CZSS is examined by density functional theory computations to deeply examine their interplay. Interestingly, after structural optimization of the slab model of CZSS (0 0 2) facet, the Cu, Zn and S atoms at the outermost layer rearrange and almost present at the same plane, whereas the Sn atoms remain out of the plane [23,24]. Then, all possible sites are tested for lithium sulfides landing on the CZSS (0 0 2) facet (Fig. S6). We further employ the adsorption energy E ads to evaluate the adsorption behavior of lithium sulfides on the surface. Fig. 4 provides the most stable adsorption configurations of Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, and Li2S on the (0 0 2) facet of wurtzite CZSS with adsorption energies of −1.045, −0.761, −0.873 and −2.367 eV, respectively. More carefully observing the most stable configurations, one can find that lithium sulfides prefer to be located on the surface containing Cu, Zn and S atoms. Li atoms interact with surrounding S atoms of the CZSS (0 0 2) surface, while S atoms of the lithium sulfides prefer to the neighboring Cu and/or Zn atoms [11]. To better understand the bonding feature between lithium sulfides and CZSS, the electronic properties are examined via the Bader charge analysis and charge density difference. From Fig. 4, the yellow regions concentrated S atoms and cyan regions surrounded Li atoms demonstrate that they are electron acceptors and donors, respectively. The charge depletion and accumulation around S and Li atoms in the charge density difference suggest a typical covalent bond feature for S–S bonds and an ionic bond character for S–Li bonds. Further, the Bader charge analysis reveals that the two Li atoms in Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, and Li2S species donate 1.718, 1.72, 1.706 and 1.733 |e|, respectively, while S atom(s) in Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, and Li2S species gain 1.582, 1.591, 1.505, and 1.268 |e|, respectively. This indicates that per Li atom in lithium sulfides denotes nearly equal charge, while the gained electrons per S decrease with increasing the number of the sulfur cluster. From the Bader charge analysis, one can find that Li atoms not only donate electrons to S atoms in lithium sulfides, but also transfer electrons to the S atoms in CZSS. Based on above-mentioned results, among lithium sulfides, the Li2S has the strongest adsorption capacity, which is in good accordance with the results of adsorption energy. 4 Conclusions In summary, we report a facile strategy for the controllable synthesis of multimetallic sulfides with highly exposed (0 0 2) facets. As a sulfur host for lithium-polysulfide batteries, the CZSS materials have superior electrochemical performance. The CZSS-based lithium-polysulfide cells have an initial capacity of 1200 mAh/g and remain 580 mAh/g at 0.5 mA/cm2 with 1.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading after 1000 cycling. In the quick-acting cell running, its initial capacity is 1068 mAh/g and the capacity after 500 cycles approaches to 480 mAh/g with 2.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading at 0.8 mA/cm2. This work offers a facile strategy for the multifunctional material design and may provide the prospect of designing highly efficient multi-active sites, which not only enhances the multi-chained polysulfide redox kinetics, but also moderates the diffusion of polysulfides. coredata.dc:description: The lithium-sulfur battery has attracted enormous attention as being one of the most significant energy storage technologies due to its high energy density and cost-effectiveness. However, the “shuttle effect” of polysulfide intermediates represents a formidable challenge towards its wide applications. Herein, we have designed and synthesized two-dimensional Cu, Zn and Sn-based multimetallic sulfide nanosheets to construct multi-active sites for the immobilization and entrapment of polysulfides with offering better performance in liquid Li2S6-based lithium-polysulfide batteries. Both experimental measurements and theoretical computations demonstrate that the interfacial multi-active sites of multimetallic sulfides not only accelerate the multi-chained redox reactions of highly diffusible polysulfides, but also strengthen affinities toward polysulfides. By adopting multimetallic sulfide nanosheets as the sulfur host, the liquid Li2S6-based cell exhibits an impressive rate capability with 1200 mAh/g and retains 580 mAh/g at 0.5 mA/cm2 after 1000 cycles. With high sulfur mass loading conditions, the cell with 2.0 mg/cm2 sulfur loading delivers a cell capacity of 1068 mAh/g and maintains 480 mAh/g with 0.8 mA/cm2 and 500 cycles. This study provides new insights into the multifunctional material design with multi-active sites for elevated lithium-polysulfide batteries.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: Two-dimensional multimetallic sulfide nanosheets with multi-active sites to enhance polysulfide redox reactions in liquid Li2S6-based lithium-polysulfide batteries
